lessons.title: First Greetings
lessons.goal: Politely greet an adult stranger and respond to "How are you?"
lessons.grammarFocus: Singular vs plural of respect (-i suffix)
cultureNotes: Importance of first greetings and response etiquette in Shona culture
Accompanying clapping when greeting elders

activities.description: Mimic-the-audio chant: Learners repeat recorded greetings after native speaker.
Dialogue scramble – arrange shuffled greeting phrases in correct order.
Pair practice: introduce yourself to a virtual character using proper greeting formality.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction. Automatic speech evaluation checks for correct greeting form and pronunciation.

exercises.question: What does 'Mhoro' mean?
Which greeting is appropriate for addressing an elder?
Translate to English: Makadii?

lessons.title: Introducing Yourself
lessons.goal: State your name and where you are from.
lessons.grammarFocus: Subject prefix ndi- (I), phrases 'Zita rangu ndi…' and 'Ndinonzi…', preposition 'ku' for origin.
cultureNotes: When introducing yourself to elders, add a respectful plural form when addressing them.
Handshakes are light; clapping once before speaking shows politeness.

activities.description: Audio echo: repeat full introduction sentences after native speaker.
Drag-and-drop jigsaw: build the sentence 'Zita rangu ndi ___' from word blocks.
Meet-and-greet: record a short intro including name & hometown; the AI avatar replies.

lessons.assessment: Learner records a 30-second self-introduction; speech evaluation checks correct structure and pronunciation.

exercises.question: How do you say 'My name is…' in Shona?
Translate to English: Ndinobva kuHarare.
Which word in Shona means 'I am called'?

lessons.title: Farewells & Small Talk
lessons.goal: End a conversation politely and perform basic leave-takings.
lessons.grammarFocus: Plural forms for respect and future tense marker 'ticha-' in 'tichasangana'.
cultureNotes: 'Sarayi zvakanaka' is used when the other person is staying; 'Fambai zvakanaka' when they are leaving.
It is common to clap lightly once or twice while saying farewell to an elder.

activities.description: Call-and-response farewell chorus.
Match Shona farewells to their English meanings.
Simulated good-bye conversation choosing correct phrases for given context.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice quiz on selecting correct farewell based on scenario.

exercises.question: What does 'Sarayi zvakanaka' mean?
Translate to English: Fambai zvakanaka.
Which phrase means 'We will meet again'?

lessons.title: Checkpoint Challenge: Café Line-up
lessons.goal: Apply greetings, introductions and farewells in a timed café scenario.
lessons.grammarFocus: Consolidation of plural respectful forms and introduction phrases.
cultureNotes: Politeness is key when ordering; greet before requesting service.
Queue etiquette: allow elders to go first if possible.

activities.description: Interactive café queue: choose correct greeting, introduce yourself to barista, end with proper farewell.
60-second rapid-fire greetings vs farewells identification.

lessons.assessment: Scenario score: must reach 80% correct selections within time limit to pass.

exercises.question: Match each Shona phrase to its English meaning.
Which greeting should you use for a group of elders?

lessons.title: Family Members Vocabulary
lessons.goal: Identify and pronounce core Shona terms for immediate and extended family members.
lessons.grammarFocus: Introduction to Noun Classes 1/1a (singular human) and 2/2a (plural human). Singular prefix 'mu-/ø', plural 'va-/ø'.
cultureNotes: In Shona culture, titles like Sekuru (grandfather/older man) and Ambuya (grandmother/older woman) extend beyond blood relations to show respect to elders.
Kinship terms are frequently used as honorifics even for non-family members, stressing community bonds.

activities.description: Flashcard reveal: learners guess the English for each family member word after hearing audio.
Drag words into 'Singular' or 'Plural' baskets to visualize noun class pairings.
Show a picture of a family; learner labels each person aloud using correct Shona term.

lessons.assessment: Picture selection quiz: choose the correct Shona word when shown an image of a family member.

exercises.question: What does 'Amai' mean?
Translate to English: Sekuru
Match the singular form to its plural.

lessons.title: Possessive Pronouns (-angu / -ako)
lessons.goal: Use possessive pronouns to describe one's own and others' family members.
lessons.grammarFocus: Possessive suffixes agree with noun class: -angu (my), -ako (your, sg.), -edu (our) for Class 1 nouns (prefix va- in plural).
cultureNotes: Saying 'Baba vangu' (my father) still uses plural prefix 'va-' on the noun to show respect, even though referring to one person.
Ownership is implicit; avoid overusing possessives with elders to maintain humility.

activities.description: Listen & repeat: sample sentences with possessives.
Drag the correct possessive ending onto noun stems (e.g., baba ___).
Learner asks virtual partner about their family and fills table using -ako / -angu.

lessons.assessment: Fill-in-the-blank quiz: supply correct possessive ending for given noun.

exercises.question: How do you say 'my brother' in Shona?
Translate to Shona: Your mother.
Which possessive suffix means 'our'?

lessons.title: Talking About Ages
lessons.goal: State ages of family members using numbers 1-20 and the structure 'ane ___ makore'.
lessons.grammarFocus: Numbers 1-20; verb form 'ane' (he/she has) from root -va with possessive of age 'makore'.
cultureNotes: In everyday speech, Shona uses 'kuva nemakore' (to have years) instead of 'to be' a certain age.
Elders' exact ages may be avoided; approximate expressions show respect.

activities.description: Quickfire counting game 1-20 with audio.
Learner receives virtual family cards with ages in digits; must state each age aloud in Shona sentences.
The app shows a picture; learner guesses age then reveals correct answer with audio.

lessons.assessment: Oral quiz: say the age displayed; automatic speech recognition scores pronunciation and accuracy.

exercises.question: Translate to English: Ane gumi nematatu makore.
What is 15 in Shona?
Complete the sentence: Baba vangu ___ makore.

lessons.title: Checkpoint: Digital Family Tree
lessons.goal: Create and present a simple digital family tree using learned vocabulary and grammar.
lessons.grammarFocus: Review of noun classes 1/2 and possessive structures.
cultureNotes: Family lineage (mutupo) is crucial in Shona identity; learners are encouraged to ask about totems respectfully.
Presenting elders first in a family introduction shows respect.

activities.description: Drag-and-drop avatars onto a tree diagram, label each with correct Shona term and possessive.
Learner records 45-second narration of their tree; AI provides feedback.

lessons.assessment: Score combines correct labels (80%) and oral narration clarity (20%). Must reach 85% to unlock next unit.

exercises.question: Match the phrase to who it describes.
Which noun class pair is used for people?

lessons.title: Staple Foods
lessons.goal: Name core Zimbabwean foods and express likes using the verb 'kuda'.
lessons.grammarFocus: Present habitual tense marker -no- with subject prefixes (ndino-, unono-, ano-) and verb 'kuda' for preferences.
cultureNotes: Sadza is the staple dish eaten with hands; learners discover etiquette of hand washing before meals.
Vegetables (muriwo) often accompany sadza; meat (nyama) is a treat.

activities.description: Audio flashcards: hear food word, select correct picture.
Learner taps thumbs-up or down for foods; app forms sentences like 'Unoda sadza?'.
Drag subject/verb/object tiles to build 'Ndinoda ____' statements.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice and translation quiz on vocabulary and 'kuda' sentences.

exercises.question: What does 'sadza' refer to?
Translate to Shona: I like meat.
Which pronoun prefix completes '__noda chingwa' for 'you (singular) like bread'?

lessons.title: At the Market
lessons.goal: Ask for prices and count money when shopping for food items.
lessons.grammarFocus: Question word 'imarii?' (how much) and number review 1-10; polite request particle '-wo' as in 'ndipeiwo'.
cultureNotes: Bargaining is normal; greet the vendor before asking for price.
Use small US dollar bills or RTGS; vendors appreciate exact change.

activities.description: Interactive audio of buyer & vendor; learner fills missing price words.
Match spoken price to the correct digit card.
Choose items in virtual stall, ask 'Imarii?' and respond appropriately.

lessons.assessment: Scenario-based quiz: purchase three items within a budget using correct phrases.

exercises.question: Translate to English: Ndapota, ndipeiwo maputi.
What does 'imarii?' mean?
Choose the correct Shona for 'five dollars'.

lessons.title: Polite Requests
lessons.goal: Use polite request forms when asking for food or drink.
lessons.grammarFocus: Particle '-wo' to soften requests; imperative plural for respect when speaking to a server.
cultureNotes: Adding '-wo' and greeting first conveys politeness; avoid commanding tone.
Right hand is used to receive food or money; support right forearm with left when respectful.

activities.description: Repeat-after-me polite request phrases.
Convert direct commands into polite forms using '-wo'.
Select correct polite phrase for each ordering scenario.

lessons.assessment: Multiple-choice questions on polite vs direct forms; audio pronunciation check.

exercises.question: Which phrase is most polite when asking for water?
Translate to Shona: Please give me vegetables.
Match Shona request to its English meaning.
options: Ndikumbirawo nyama-May I have meat please

lessons.title: Restaurant Role-play
lessons.goal: Order a meal politely and respond to questions from the waiter.
lessons.grammarFocus: Future tense 'ndichatora' (I will take) and question 'munoda chii?' (what would you like?), consolidation of polite forms.
cultureNotes: Tip is not obligatory but appreciated in urban restaurants.
Always thank the server with 'Ndatenda' after receiving service.

activities.description: Timed ordering game: select starter, main, drink using voice recognition.
Listen to waiter questions and choose correct answer.

lessons.assessment: Pass score 80% on ordering simulation to unlock next unit.

exercises.question: What does the waiter ask with 'Munoda chii?'
Translate to Shona: Thank you for the food.
Match phrase to function.
